Entry.1: Left Heliopolis Camp about 8.30 p.m. and entrained for Alexandria, which we reached at about 4.30 a.m. Monday morning.
Entry.2: Came on board "Saturnia" a rotten tub filthy and covered with coal dust. Have mounted the guns on the after deck and the Section is on guard on lookout for Submarines.
Entry.3: Still on guard on deck. No excitement so far. Lifebelt parade to-day.
Entry.4: as yesterday. Expect to reach Lemnos Island to-night. Submarine guard doubled. Saw Volcano at night. The blue of meditteranean is remarkable. Did not reach Lemnos.
Entry.5: At Lemnos. The Harbour is filled with hundreds of Troopships and Battleships etc.
Entry.6: Had a swim. Are now on board "Osmaniet" which is a fine boat. Very clean. Bound for the Dardanelles. Time 6.30 leaving.
Entry.7: Arrived at Gaba Tebe at about 3 a.m. Landing uneventful. A few stray bullets, but no wounded. An awful climb to the rear of trenches with the guns. Am leaving to-night for the firing line.
Entry.8: Am camped in dugouts just behind the line. Great danger from flying bullets and shrapnel. Several wounded. Just leaving for the front. Later:- have had a rather gruelling experience. Just up in a trench as reserves in the firing line. Had to double across about 200 yds by shrapnel swept open land with the guns was no light job and am still absolutely knocked up. Several killed and many wounded, including Mr. Killeen.
Entry.9: Still in trenches as reserves, but are moving still further along to-night.
Entry.10: (Morning) Orders came along last night cancelling and we are still in our dugout. Very cold of a night and we have no coats or blankets.
Entry.11: Still in the same place. A party went back to base and brought all our overcoats. Also went down to have a swim. On guard to-night.
Entry.12: (Morning) Still here. Had another swim. Moving further on to-night.
Entry.13: Have just gone through an experience which I don’t want again. We left our trench at about 7 p.m. and reached here Pope’s Post 12 p.m. March ed eight miles over mountains with the guns under fire practically the whole way, and was absolutely knocked up when we reached here. Half the Section was separated and have only just reached here 3 o’clock in the afternoon. This is awful. Later:- March ed up to our position on Courtney’s Post.
Entry.14: Have settled down here and have been in action. Firing at intervals all day as opportunity offers. Can see very little as to results, as we only see periscopes of Turks rifles above the trenches. Also firing with rifles from Gun position which are very safe. Am on regular guard – three hours on and six off. Pretty bad with dysentery, most of the Section have it.
Entry.15: Still on same duty, not much excitement. Several mines exploded by us shook our position somewhat. Sent P.C. home. Still bad with dysentery.
Entry.17: Very much the same much better.
Entry.18: An attack was expected to-night, but never eventuated.
Entry.19: Wrote to Pat. Still expect attack. Major Murray (?) killed by sniper, also J. Robinson.
Entry.21: 1915 No excitement. The six Brigade have relieved the
Entry.22: Battalion, which were here about four months. A Turk wandered into trenches last night and gave himself up. Don very bad.
Entry.23: As per usual. Don still bad.
Entry.24: Went away to Murdois Island for a rest.
Entry.25: as before, pretty sick. We are now doing eighteen hours guard and eighteen off. Most of the Section are sick including Harry.
Entry.26: Simpson sent away to Murdois sick. Getting cold.
Entry.29: Bit of demonstration on both sides to-night. Shells landed very close to our position.
Entry.30:
Attack by both sides; about tea time to-night we had superiority of fire, bombs very close, they found

the range of our trenches, and knocked the parapets about, several of the
Entry.31: killed. The guns were not in action.
Entry.32: Had a swim, very cold. Eight reserve men from the Battalion came up to-day for training.
Entry.33: Little excitement to-day. A shed caught fire, had some difficulty in putting it out. Fumes from W, proofs and equipments was awful. Also danger from exploding cartridges.
Entry.34: To-night we had the guns in action, but failed to draw very much opposition.
Entry.35: Ralph Mace killed by shell on Pope’s.
Entry.38: Mail in – 12 letters – also a few Regimental comforts.
Entry.39: Section took over two more guns on Quinn’s Post. 7 men from this Section including Sergeant and Corporal Harris, also 12 men from
Entry.41: Shrapnel at our No. 1 position this morning, no result.
Entry.44: McShane & Morris both sent away with yellow jaundice. Letter from Mrs. McKnight.
Entry.45: Shifted from Courtney’s to Pope’s. Sorry to lose a comfortable position.
Entry.46: Snowing to-night, very cold, feet frozen three days silence.
Entry.48: Splinter of bullet in shoulder. Night off duty.
Entry.50: Harry Smith hit – splinters on the neck. Corpe hit on forhead, and Brown on finger. All from same Rieochell during stand to.
Entry.52: Left Pope’s 5.30. From amb to beach 35 minute. All aboard without a shot fired. 11 Gun Sec left behind, 7 men and O.C. on Pope’s and 4 on Pluggs Plateau. On board H.M.S. Mers – Now at Lemnos enjoying ourselves shifting tents.
Entry.54: (Xmas Day) Had a swim, very cold, but feel cleaner. Dinner: stew.
Entry.55: billies arrived (Victorian) very much appreciated, mine from Mrs. Vickery, "Glynn" Seymour Grove, Brighton Beach, Melbourne, Vic.
Entry.56: (New Year’s Day) very quiet, raining. Saw the N.Y. in plenty noise.
Entry.57: Walked to Castro 45 miles. Had a hot Spring Bath.
Entry.58: Left Lemnos and came aboard "Ascanius" at night.
Entry.59: Have mounted the guns on Poop deck, and am on guard against Submarines etc. Rather rough.
Entry.60: Arrived Alexandria about 9 a.m. Left boat about 6 p.m., entrained in same old cattle trucks and reached our Camp Tel-el Keber about 3 a.m.
Entry.61: Don’t think much of this place. Muddle of desert, and up to present have no tents. Big issue of mail etc. Received 43 letters and three parcels.
Entry.62: Put up tents. 8 men and Corporal went to Zeitoun school. Met Harry Rogers. Received two parcels and billy from home.
Entry.65: Went out to ranges for a shooting practice. Had a great opportunity of viewing the wonderful irrigation scheme. Small mail in.
Entry.66: Left Tel-el-Kebir. Reveille at 12.45 a.m. entrained about 2 and reached Ismalia about
Entry.67: ed over 5 miles through beautiful avenues and reached here (about one mile from Ferry Post) about 8 o’clock.
Entry.68: was again sent into Hospital – mumps.
Entry.69:
Left Camp at about 9 a.m. and March ed about 8 miles in heavy sand to our present camp, or Pinch Gut Hollow.

Very tired when we got here.
Entry.70: Tucker is very off. Bully and biscuits only so far.
Entry.71: ) Church Service to-day at 11.30 a.m. This afternoon the Gun Section played the Signallers of Battalion Football, Rugby Union. Heavy sand, therefore slow. Won 9 to 0 Mr. Saddler – Referee. Tucker no different.
Entry.72: Much the same beginning to get a bit monotonous. We are doing very interesting work with the guns, as the work is very different from Gallipoli. The tucker is about worse. We get issued with about three biscuits a day per man and no bully. Two meat stews a day is supposed to keep us alive. Filling in our spare time with 500 and getting about sick of that. Issued with ¼ oz tobacco and packet of cigarettes to-day.
Entry.73: Great excitement. A small mail arrived to-night, three letters for me, dated 26th December.
Entry.74: Rest of the Battalion arrived to-day at 4 p.m. also rest of the Section except Winthorp who broke leave. Corporal Carmichael and Hill with Instructors Ticket and all the rest except Winthorp have 1st class tickets. We also got some fruit in per camel.
Entry.75: To-day "C" Coy refused to parade in March ing order. Result about 12 men in Guard Tent. Work on Barr and Stroud to-day.
Entry.76: 7 more men out of the Section went to Zeitoun School to-day. This afternoon Reinforcements came for the Coys. Amongst them were Bingham and Whalen.
Entry.77: Church Parade this morning. Spent a quiet day in which I wrote letters.
Entry.78: Aeroplane came out to day and circled round our Camp several times. The
Entry.79: Band played a few selections after tea to-night, which was rather good and was practically the first music we have heard since leaving the Pen.
Entry.80: Went out to trenches this afternoon for drill.
Entry.81: Small mail in to-day but no luck.
Entry.82: Paid to-day £3/-/- each. Mail in to-night and also more on Sunday . 18 letters, no papers. Had to drill Sunday morning. Church 4 p.m.
Entry.83: Harris and Luke went to Hospital to-day with mumps.
Entry.84:
Big mail in to-day and also our comforts from

Ismalia.
Entry.85: A new gun came in to-day from Brig. This evening shifted the Camp round. Usual mess up. Ellis and Bingham had a slight difference to-night and resorted to fists. Bingham won. Had best wind.
Entry.87: Started digging our Gun Pits to-day. Very hard work as the blisters on my hands will testify. Also got in some canteen stores, and am feeling full in consequence.
Entry.88: Birthday to-day, spent it digging trenches four parcels arrived, two from home, one from Pevensey, one from Dos.
Entry.89: Went into Ferry Post and put up at Rest Camp, very cold night and rotten walk in.
Entry.90: Early morning, walked into Esmalia and caught train to Cairo, arrived 9.30. Met Don. Went out to Maadi to see Chas and Os, but missed them. Gone night before. Put up at Bristol that night and imagined myself a gentleman again.
Entry.91: Left Cairo at 11 and reached Camp at about 5 p.m. caught train back. Small mail in when got here.
Entry.92: All packed up to-day ready to go over to H.Q. being transferred, but order was cancelled till Battalion got Lewis guns.
Entry.93: The Battalion changed rifles to-day for M.K. 4 M.V. firing mark 7 ammunition.
Entry.94: Early this morning all our guns, gear etc., went away and Pte Hamilton, Corporal Carr and three men went into Ferry Post to draw New Vicars.
Entry.95: The Battalion moved this morning to Rest Camp at Ferry Post but unfortunately I was not with them. Being a bit off I was sent to 5th Field Hospital.
Entry.96: The Hospital moved this morning and carted me along with them. My first experience of a ride in an Ambulance Waggon.
Entry.97: Now at Maadi? Still in Hospital. Had a good walk this morning.
Entry.98: Regained the Section. Don is back again.
Entry.100: Paid to-day, also got our black kit bags.
Entry.103: Filling belts to-day, leaving to-morrow Saturday. Parade. Simpson came back.
Entry.104: General mix up, packing up etc.
Entry.105: Duty Sec. Packing up etc. Left Camp at about 7 o’clock. Baggage Guard, entrained at about 12 in same old cattle trucks only for a change this time the truck was covered in coal dust.
Entry.106: Train left 1.55 a.m. and arrived at Alexandria about 10 a.m. after a very cold night. Came on board "Arcadian" H 1 at 11.45 worked like blazes all day, loading gear etc. Left Egypt at 5.45. Slept on deck. Weather very wintry and wet, but got in a good sleep. Two guns mounted, but was too rough to keep them up.
Entry.107: Still very rough, several sick, 2,300 troops aboard. Very rough day. Innoculation.
Entry.108: Rough night. Feeling effects of innoculation.
Entry.109: Calm to-day, tried all guns, all very satisfactory. Passed Malta at about 4.30. On Guard to-night.
Entry.110: Rough weather. Had to dismount guns.
Entry.111: Still fairly rough. Put the guns up again last night, but had to dismount them this morning. Our destination in sight to-night. Everybody is packing up. General confusion.
Entry.112: Up at 5 a.m. this morning. Had a hot bath, came on deck and saw magnificient sight. The Sun was just rising over the Hills which surround Marseilles, and the white Cliffs looked fine. We are now in the Quay and busily engaged tasting the fine oranges. The Harbour, what there is of it is mostly artificial. The view as we first saw it looked very like Gallipoli. A Railway and Tram line runs along the shore. Later:- disembarked a fairly long wait on the Wharf during which we had Dinner. Then a March for about a mile to the Station. We did not see too much of the town, but we were struck with the beauty of the women and the scarcity of the men folk. Of course we had a good reception. Arriving at the Railway we were very much surprised at the class of carriages we had to travel in. They certainly were a fine contrast to the old animal trucks of Egypt. We tried our very poor French here to bad effect. Train left at about 4 o’clock and we travelled through the most glorious scenery until dark. Passed through five tunnels, the last one being about three miles long.
Entry.113:
Had a fairly comfortable night though we were

wakened up at 11 o’clock to a drink of tea. Think we would have rather had the sleep. The same beautiful scenery this morning. Passing through Vineyards and olive groves this morning. Passed Lyon at 6.10 a.m. A fine town what we could see of it. Passed over the Rhone here. Fine Bridges. Getting a great reception from the inhabitants of the Villages we pass. Ravages of war are apparent. All the women are in black and no men of military age are visible. Rain spoilt the day somewhat. Later on: Travelling very slowly.
Entry.114: Had a very cold night. Frost and ice on the ground this morning. Stopped for tea at 4.30 a.m. Same class of scenery. Reached Monterause at 12. Had dinner here, returned at 2. Were very disappointed at not seeing Paris. We branched off about 13 miles beforehand at Jowish. Saw outskirts of it later on. Reached Versailles at about 5 p.m. where the ladies of the Crois Rouge Francais handed us tea and bread and generally treated us fine. So far we have a very fine opinion of French hospitality.
Entry.115: Another cool night. We are now getting close to firing line. Arrived at Thiennes at about 12 o’clock, 70 hours in the train, where we detrained. Were issued with a blanket here. March ed 3 K through Villages. Are now billited in the barn of a farmhouse. Pretty comfortable. Bed of straw on floor. Walked down Village where we made the acquaintance of all the pretty girls and exercised our French. Plenty of wine and beer at 1d glass to be had.
Entry.116: Cool morning. Cleaned guns this morning raining nearly all day. Very cool. Cleaned ammunition this afternoon.
Entry.117: Very cold day. March ed to Aire this afternoon 4 K.
Entry.118: Half Holiday to-day. Went to Aire. Not a bad little place. Bought a few odds and ends. There was a slight fall of snow while we were there.
Entry.119: 19th Batt played the fool to-night and in consequence all Pubs were shut, but opened later.
Entry.120: March ed four miles to-day and had our first experience of being gassed, not too pleasant. Reached home at 3 o’clock – very hungry.
Entry.121: A few of us went to Morebecque to-day and saw a demonstration of liquid fire. Put under arrest.
Entry.123: Packing up and cleaning the guns ready for shifting, usual mix up.
Entry.124: March ed off with full packs (our blankets were carried for us) at 8 o’clock and joined the rest of the Brigade at about 10 a.m. At about five miles out we were received by Gen Joffre and staff. The General was just about as I expected to find him. Altogether we March ed about 18 or 20 miles and by the time we reached our billet we were tired out. Passed through numerous Villages on the way.
Entry.125: Next morning off again at 9.30 and did about 12 miles to our present billet a few miles behind the firing line and in range.
Entry.126: Got the guns ready for action, No 2 Sec and Nos 1 and 2 guns of our Section went up to firing line to-night.
Entry.127: Expecting to leave any minute. Everything ready.
Entry.128: Moved further up into another billet. Two more guns went up.
Entry.129: Three men from Company and self came to school for overhead and indirect fire, four miles from Groise der Boe Billet.
Entry.130: Lecture at 2 p.m. on culminating points.
Entry.131: Left school and came back to billet. Had a fairly good time though place was very slow.
Entry.132: Shifted into another billet nearer the line.
Entry.133: Had a trip up to the trenches to-night with rations. Very wet. Rather exciting.
Entry.134: Had a hot bath and clean change.
Entry.135: Came up to the trenches to-day. Got lost on the way up, but eventually reached our position in a Graveyard. Don and I are in one dugout and very comfortable. Only watch at night. Have a good stove and cook for ourselves.
Entry.136: Some of the boys thought they had caught a spy very amusing. Shrapnel over to-day.
Entry.138: George Ball and Darkie Mill went to town to-day and came home slightly irresponsible. Looked as if they swam home. George had both pockets full of eggs which also got mixed up in the struggle. Raining heavy to-day.
Entry.139: Fined up this morning, plenty shells. Saw about 200 shells at aeroplane without result.
Entry.140: Six men under Harry took over position near
Entry.142: Vigorous bombardment of our second line. Very little damage.
Entry.143: Very heavy bombardment on both sides to-night. Rumors of gas attack and we all turned out about 11 p.m. with helmets. Fortunately only a rumor.
Entry.144: Left our post and went back to billets for a spell.
Entry.146: Went in and had our Photos taken don, Ern and self.
Entry.148: Up again in trenches to-day this time closer up to White City. Things pretty lively.
Entry.149: At 7.15 to-night while Don and I were down for rations a heavy bombardment started, which gave our positions a terrible doing. Stafford, Flabman and Wheeler were killed in our Pit which was blown right out. At Emma Post three men were buried. Sgt Carmichael was rather seriously injured. Bombardment lasted for nearly three hours and other casualties were heavy. A very long and cold night. I lost all my clothes and things in my dugout.
Entry.150:
After sitting up all night expecting another attack we were relieved at 2 p.m. much to our delight as we were all pretty merry.

From
Entry.153: Came up into White City again. Have plenty of work to do as we are rebuilding possey. Gas alarms all night.
Entry.155: Finished the dugout. Few shells over. Having beautiful weather.
Entry.157: Into No 11 Cemetry Post. Mail in before we left.
Entry.158: A heavy bombardment on our right caused a stand to at about 10 p.m. but nothing eventuated.
Entry.159: Aeroplane duel this afternoon. Taube went down. Later on one of ours came down. A captured balloon of ours broke loose and floated out of sight. This evening they bombarded our position and caused a scatter.
Entry.160: Came up into Firing Line to-day. Captain Tate and six men.
Entry.161: An Artillery duel on our right caused a stand to at night. Some shells over in the day.
Entry.162: Shelling very close. 7th Brigade intended doing a stunt to-night and had to stand to from 9 p.m. till 3.30 a.m., stunt never came off.
Entry.163: Standing to all night again. At 11.30 our Artillery opened out on to Fritz’s parapets. Fritz paid it back with interest and things got lively. Not many casualties. 7th made a very successful raid.
Entry.165: Quiet day. Raining bombs at night.
Entry.166: A lively day with shells and bombs.
Entry.167: Fairly quiet day, bombs and shells.
Entry.168: To-night at about 11 p.m. Allemand? started to throw bombs which we paid back with compound interest. Artillery opened up and things got very mixed for a while.
Entry.169: Another stand to to-night when we had to submit to bombardment while the 1st Brigade did a stunt.
Entry.170: Relieved to-day thank goodness. Had a very lively ten days.
Entry.171: Clocks put forward an hour. Concert to-night great success.
Entry.173: Came up into White City. Harry S. in charge. A lively night. Stood to about three times for bombardments. Received two parcels from home and tobacco from Mr. Pauch.
Entry.174: Very cold day. Plenty of shelling. Up again twice during the night. Fritz seems to have developed a habit of annoying us.
Entry.176: Battalion men came to look over to-day, so our dreams of a spell seem to be materialising. The Company had bad luck to-day. A shell hit the billet (intended for a Battery behind) and killed four men and wounded eleven. No. 2 Section and reinforcements.
Entry.177: To-night a bombardment on both sides. Shells very close to us but no damage, also gas alarm.
Entry.178: Up again to-night for bombardment, violent storm ce soir.
Entry.179: Twice out to-night and two gas alarms.
Entry.180: Twelve months to-day since we left Sydney. Places seen in that time. Suez, Port Said, Alexandria (3) Heliopolis, Cairo (2) Lemnos (2) Gallipoli, Tel-el-Kebir, Ismalia, Ferry Post, Mount Katoomba (Sinai) Moascar, Marseilles (France). By way of celebration, after a heavy bombardment which lasted nearly two hours, the 5th Brigade made a successful raid on the German trenches. Saw a peculiar cloud effect in the afternoon. Shrapnel at ‘plane broke clouds.
Entry.181: Two observation balloons destRoyed by our planes this afternoon and four more forced to descend. To-night was extremely lively. Fritz got in on us and gave us a lively time for about an hour. Starting at 9 o’clock and kept it up every half hour for about three hours. However, we replied vigorously and quietened him. Later on we gave him his own back with interest and incidentally carried out a successful raid and repulsed one by Fritz leaving.
Entry.182: Bustling around to-day getting ready to hand over. Some bustle too. Relieved at about 11.30 tonight. The boys were filling in time with the rum issue and were rather funny. I had to stop behind all night and hand over. No sleep, raining all night. Just as they left a stunt happened on the right and mixed things up.
Entry.183: Came out about 8.30 and had to set to work cleaning the gun which was covered with mud. Nos 3 and 4 Sections moved off.
Entry.184: Before moving off to-night we had a small concert most amusing. Came in to Erquingham and are now in huts. Heavy bombardment, a soir.
Entry.185:
Looking over gun belts etc., and generally straightening up.

From
Entry.187: old thing. All the boys seem to be having birthdays which have to be celebrated.
Entry.190: On the move again. Left Erquingham at 11.15 a.m. and reached Strabeele at 7.30. March ed about 10 miles. Everybody with sore feet.
Entry.191: On the move again, 12 miles to Eblingham. Fine billet old Chateau.
Entry.192: Up early this morning March ed 10 miles to Wizarnes and entrained 40 miles in three days, pretty well knocked up. Sore feet.
Entry.193: Detrained at 2 a.m. after passing through Calais, Bolougne, Etaples, unloaded horses and limbers and then set out per hoof again. Did about 15 miles going about 6 miles out of our way and finally pulled up at Picquigney. Very slow town though big.
Entry.194: To-night we had a look at some historical ruins. An old Chateau of 12th Century and a Church of
Entry.195: The Chateau is crumbling down but the old Church is in a marvellous state of repair.
Entry.196: Off again to-day immediately after Church Parade (the first in France). We set off and did about 12 miles in fast time. Are now at Coisy.
Entry.197: Left again and reached Rubenprt, only six miles this time. Good Billet.
Entry.198: Now at WalRoy Baillon, 8 miles to-day. Getting close up.
Entry.199:
Witness at F.G.C.M. to-day J. Hill.

22nd July 1916 Packing up again off at 7 p.m. reached out-skirts of Albert and bivouacked.

23rd July 1916 Heavy bombardment last night. 1st Division took and held Pozieres. Packs handed in.

24th July 1916 Moved to-day and bivouacked a couple of miles behind the line, in fact on the British original front line.

25th July 1916 Had a look at the first system of German trenches to-day. Ground simply ploughed up, bombardment must have been terrific. Saw Crater blown up by us on 1st July over 100 yds across top. Said to be over 600 buried in it. Moved up to front line to-night and got lost and took over from 3rd M.G. Company6.

26th July 1916 All 1st Division got away this morning, 19th are holding Pozieres, 17th 18th and 20th on right and 6th and
Entry.200: Brigade in Reserve. Tommies on both flanks. Welsh on our right planned a bomb attack, but on being repulsed called on our Company, the
Entry.201: went out and took on a battle with bombs which lasted over eighteen hours.
Entry.202:
The fight which extended through the bombers of the whole Brigade lasted through the night and well on in the

morning, we eventually gaining our objective – 150 yds and trench. We assisted as much as possible. It was a glorious sight and heroism and grit displayed by our boys baffles description.
Entry.203: Relieved this morning and went back amongst the Artillery. Glad to get out of the trenches where the strain is awful. Position as we found it. Things were a big mixed all right.
Entry.204: Still in reserves and carrying rations and rum to firing line.
Entry.205: Moved up to supports where we do indirect fire. An Officer captured at Pozieres said that our machine Gun fire did more damage than Artillery. We are enfilading a main sap. Some of each Brigade charged to-night, but the Artillery failing to cut the wire failed though the German line was entered at several points.
Entry.206: Still in supports and being very much worried with gas and lachrymatory shells.
Entry.207: Relieved again and backed into Reserves. Harry Austin and Plume and Hearst caught the full force of a gas shell. Afterwards all died.
Entry.208: Supplying fatigues again. Our Brigade has done marvellous work and badly needs a rest which won’t be until we take the Ridge in front away.
Entry.209: Up in front line again. Fritz is shelling like blazes. One of our guns buried and Sgt Tate killed, two others had to go out with shell shock. Rotten night.
Entry.210: 2nd Anniversary of the War and we hopped the parapet to-night. Our Artillery has been going all day and cut all the wire in front to bits. Barrage started at 9.15 and lifted 9.18, when 18 and 20 and some of the Company Brigades went over. One of our guns went.
Entry.211: Morning found us in possession of two more lines of German trenches and our chaps running about looking for Fritz. Resistance only slight. Fritz is pouring in shells like hell. Three of our boys wounded in charge.
Entry.212: We were relieved last night & glad to get out of it. It has been a great strain but I think we lived up to our reputation. We were reviewed in the forenoon by Gnl. Birdwood who expressed great appreciation of our work. These Australians will do me for fighters. In the afternoon we moved to Walhoy, Baillon, 8 miles. Going back for a short spell to re-organise and then into it again.
Entry.213: Moved again from W.B. to a small village, La Vicogane, 12 miles away and bivouaced in an orchard.
Entry.214: March ed to Pernois, a village 8 miles away, where we are to spell.
Entry.217: Resting. Went down to baths (cold). Got a complete new outfit. Tres bien!!
Entry.218: Most of the boys have taken French leave and gone to Armiens. Would have gone myself but thought a sleep would have done me more good.
Entry.219: Started a programme of work today – pretty stiff. Am training recruits.
Entry.221: Shifted again suddenly and bivouaced in the same orchard. Rained during the night and did much cursing.
Entry.222: Off again and do about 15 miles – feet gave out and did the last 7 on a limber. Now at Harponville. Good billet
Entry.225: Moved up close to Albert – No. 3 & 4 Sections went up.
Entry.226: Moved down to Sunken Road H.Q. In reserve.
Entry.227: Still H.Q. Severe shelling tonight. 2 men wounded.
Entry.228:
We moved up into trenches. Found

the position slightly altered. Incessant shelling had flattened out the trenches and we were practically in Noman’s Land. Was buried after 5 minutes in.
Entry.229: Very severe shelling. Mr. Gritten was buried – severe shaking.
Entry.230: Heavy shelling all day. Bingham Norris & Bill hit 26.
Entry.231: Relieved by 7th M.G. Coy. Very pleased to get out. Rained the whole time and very muddy and dead-beat. Came back to Limbers.
Entry.233: Moved to Walhoy Baillon – Left 8 a.m.
Entry.234: Walhoy. Canadians went through – fine lot.
Entry.235: Medals presented to heroes in 5th Bgde. Gnl. Birdwood. Left Walhoy 2 p.m. March ed to Beaval about 12 miles.
Entry.236: At Beaval – fine town and good shops.
Entry.238: Church parade today. Only few in France. Cpl. Langworthy made Sgt. & Corps Lce. Cpl.
Entry.240: Reveille 4.30 a.m. left at 5. 30 March ed to Doullens North. Entrained 44 in a cattle truck and things were very crowded. Only 6 hrs trip and pulled up at Paperingha in Belgium.
Entry.241: Still in Paperingha – fine town, plenty of shops, and people speak English.
Entry.242: Expected to move up today, but cancelled.
Entry.243:
Moving up to-night. Left billet about 8 o’clock and March ed up to Railway Station. Entrained about 9.30 in armoured train and ran with lights out to Ypres. Our first experience of going up to the line by train. Some shells pretty close to us in the train and also while we were waiting to move off. March ed through Ypres – A once beautiful city in ruins. Took over at about 12 o’clock from 11 Welsh

Tommies. My position is isolated and we are living like rabbits. Not allowed to go out of the dug-out in day time.
Entry.244: far it has been very quiet we have to watch all night and sleep in day time. Our rations are brought up at night and that is the only time we see anyone. A bit of excitement tonight – the dug-out caught fire, burning one of the boys packs and several waterproofs.
Entry.245: A mail came in tonight and a small parcel for me.
Entry.246: About 11.30 to-night we were relieved suddenly by the
Entry.247: M.G. Coy. After carrying ammunition to Tillebincke Village, came back to Coy. H. Quarters. Fine row of dugouts. Issued with a blanket and got to bed about 4.30 a.m.
Entry.248: Pay today. Moving up again tonight – Only 2 guns – Left at 9.30 p.m. and came up and took over a rotten position. Only my gun stayed, the position too precarious for another gun.
Entry.249: The 19th Div. carried out a stunt on our left using gas. There are only 2 of us at the gun, the other 3 are behind. We have to divide the all-day watch between us.
Entry.250: Another stunt on the right this time tonight. So far Fritz replies to the bombardment have been very weak, and rumours are flying around that he is rushing from Ypres front.
Entry.251: Great sadness tonight – Nothing to eat!! – something went wrong with arrangements.
Entry.252: Nearly flooded out, raining all day. Issued with rubber boots.
Entry.253: Issued with a Primus Stove for cooking. A big mail in tonight, 14 letters and a parcel of tobacco from Mr. Pauch.
Entry.254: Relieved tonight and came back to B---. 2 parcels.
Entry.255: Left B--- at 8 on leave to Blighty. Went down as far as transport in limber, and walked to Paperingha, about 2½ miles.
Entry.256: Train left at 6.5 a.m. Reached Boulogne at 2 p.m., missed boat and went to Rest Camp.
Entry.257: Left about 9.45, March ed to wharf and boat. Left at 12.45, about 2 hrs. across the Channel and reached London at 5.30 p.m. Went to Horseferry Rd. and got fixed up. Engaged a room at Kenilworth Hotel – some class – Had a hot bath, went out and had a feed and then to Cinema.
Entry.258: Went to Commonwealth Bank and drew £20/. Bought some clothes etc. Went to Euston Station and caught train to Birmingham. Took the girls to the pictures at night.
Entry.259: Went for a walk in the Park and lazed the afternoon away with ditto.
Entry.260: Met the girls in town, went to pictures. Up till 2 a.m.
Entry.261: Left for Leeds this morning, and went to see a wounded friend in hospital, and from there down to Leicester.
Entry.262: Stayed the night and came down to London again this afternoon – then going to Eastbourne. Talked all night.
Entry.264: Having a good time at Eastbourne, including a motor trip round Beachy Head, Pevensey, etc.
Entry.265: Left at 2.25 and are now at West Ealing. Went to pictures.
Entry.266: Went to Church in the morning and Brotherhood in the afternoon and listened to a speech by a Conscientious Objector.
Entry.267: Went into London for the day, visited St. Pauls, Art Gallery, Guild Hall, and theatre, Daddy Long Legs, at night.
Entry.268: Up early this morning and caught train at 8 at Victoria, arrived Folkestone about 10 and Boulogne at 1 p.m. Very rough crossing, stayed in Boulogne till 6p.m. Saw the city – narrow streets and dirty – Reached Harebrouck at abt 11.30 and stayed in a Rest Camp the night.
Entry.269: Caught train at 10 a.m. and came to Paperingah and spent the day here and night on the floor of Y.M.C.A. Hut.
Entry.270: Wakened up at 6 this morning and walked out to S--- Camp, arriving there before the Coy.
Entry.271: Left here – went to Ontario Camp Reninghalst.
Entry.272: March ed to S--- about 11 miles and walked into W--- for tea.
Entry.273: Left again this morning and March ed 16 miles in pouring rain to Arncke.
Entry.274: To-day we had to vote For or Against Conscription.
Entry.275: Another long March today to Y--- 16 miles, very good billet. Heavy frost these last two mornings.
Entry.277: Walked about 2 miles and entrained at Audrick at about 12 o’clock. Train left at 3 and we detrained at 12 p.m. after passing through Calais, Boulogne, Etaples etc. At Pontrenny where we were billeted.
Entry.278: Went into Abbyville today and had a fairly good time. It has 3 beautiful churches and a fine statue.
Entry.279: Raining like blazes today and we had to shift, March ing 6 miles in pouring rain and then got into motor cars. Travelled about 7 hrs. in these and came to ---. Had wet feet and clothing to start with, and so had a rotten trip. Came through Blixicourt, Requigney etc. Had a good billet that night.
Entry.280: Shifted billet – had to pitch tents in the mud, and pinched straw etc. to dry the floor.
Entry.281: Dropped tents this morning and shifted up to camp -. Raining all the time.
Entry.282: Went up to Reserve to 7th Bgde hop over the attack, was not too successful, but were not required.
Entry.283: Moved up to take over from the
Entry.284:
about 6 miles walk in pouring rain and mud feet deep. About

11 the shells were flying thick and I stopped a piece in right chest, walked back to dressing Station, about 4 miles through the rain and mud and spent the night there.
Entry.285: Left in an open char-a-banc and went down to 5th A.M.C. Pouring with rain and a rotten ride over rough roads. Dressed again here, and then in a motor ambulance to No. 37 C.C.S. where we spent the night.
Entry.286: Caught train at end day and reached Rouen at about midnight, and am now between clean sheets. Also wounded same night Corpe Lawrence, Lanc Cpl. W. Lawrence and I are together so far.
Entry.287: Went under X Ray today. Concert to-night.
Entry.288: Supposed to be leaving for Blighty. Left 4/30 and came on board Hospital Ship Western Australian in port that night.
Entry.289: Left 5.30 this morning, found Mr. Shane and Joe Hill on board. Heavy fog came up and we had to put back – very crook.
Entry.290: Started again this morning at 9 and reached Southampton tonight – anchored for the night.
Entry.291: Pulled into wharf at 9 a.m. and finally left in the train at about 1, and reached Bristol about 3 p.m. Had a great reception from the people. Went to Southmead Hospital.
Entry.293: Snowing to-night. First of the Year.
